title: 103_hr4476
content: The Act titled "National Park System Reform Act of 1994" includes the preparation of a National Park System Plan. The National Park System Reform Act of 1994 mandates the Secretary of the Interior to prepare a National Park System Plan, outlining goals, objectives, and criteria for the preservation of national natural and cultural heritage. The National Park System Reform Act of 1994 mandates the Secretary of the Interior to prepare a National Park System Plan, which includes detailed criteria for determining appropriate natural and cultural resources for inclusion in the system, identifying adequate representation of national heritage, and prioritizing themes and resource types. The National Park System Reform Act of 1994 mandates the Secretary of the Interior to prepare a National Park System Plan, which includes criteria for adding heritage to the system, prioritizing themes and resource types, defining the role of the National Park Service, and determining units of the National Park System. The National Park System Reform Act of 1994 requires the Secretary of the Interior to consult with various agencies and organizations during the preparation of the National Park System Plan, including public review and comment opportunities. The Secretary must consult with organizations and interested parties, including public review and comment opportunities, for the National Park System Plan. The plan must be transmitted to the Committees on Natural Resources and Energy and Natural Resources of the House and Senate within three fiscal years after the Act's enactment. SEC. 102. MANAGEMENT REVIEW OF NATIONAL PARK SYSTEM. The Secretary will review the National Park System to assess alternative management options, including partnerships with States, local governments, and the private sector. A report will be developed listing areas where National Park Service management should be modified or terminated, considering factors like duplication within the system. The Secretary will develop a list of areas in the National Park System that should be modified or terminated, considering factors like duplication, lack of significance, cost, and visitor accessibility. Recommendations for termination of National Park Service management will be made for selected areas. The Secretary will recommend management alternatives for areas in the National Park System that may be terminated, ensuring protection of resources and public access. Consultation with various agencies and officials will be conducted in developing the list of areas for modification or termination. The Secretary will consult with various agencies, officials, and interested parties to develop a plan for areas in the National Park System that may be terminated. The report will be transmitted to Congress within 1 year of completing the plan. The Secretary will submit a report to Congress with recommendations on modifying or terminating National Park Service management for areas within the National Park System, as well as suggestions for alternative management by other entities. The National Park System Review Commission is established under SEC. 103. Establishment of Commission: If the Secretary fails to transmit the report within the specified 1-year period, a National Park System Review Commission will be established to review existing units for better management alternatives. The Commission will prepare and submit a report to the House Natural Resources Committee and the Senate Energy and Natural Resources Committee within one year of its establishment. The Commission will provide a report to Congress listing National Park System units for potential modification or termination, considering specified factors. Feasible alternatives to National Park Service management will be suggested for listed areas of national significance. The Commission will identify feasible alternatives to National Park Service management for listed areas of national significance, consulting with various agencies and stakeholders for input. Membership of the Commission will consist of 7 members. The Commission, consisting of 7 members familiar with the National Park System, will be appointed by the Secretary, Speaker of the House, and President Pro Tem of the Senate. Each member will be appointed within 3 months after a specified period. The Commission, consisting of 7 members familiar with the National Park System, will elect a chair from among its members. Vacancies will not affect the Commission's authority, and any vacancy will be promptly filled in the same manner as the original appointment. A simple majority of members will constitute a quorum for meetings held at least quarterly or upon the call of the chair or a majority of members. The Commission, with 7 members familiar with the National Park System, will elect a chair. Vacancies will be promptly filled. A simple majority constitutes a quorum for quarterly meetings or upon the call of the chair. Members serve without compensation but are entitled to travel expenses. The Commission will terminate 90 days after the report is transmitted to Congress. The Commission established under this section will terminate 90 days after the report is sent to Congress. The Commission can hire staff, with no more than half being National Park Service employees. Other federal agencies can detail personnel to assist the Commission. The Commission may procure temporary services and hold public hearings for carrying out its duties under this title. It can also make bylaws, rules, and regulations as needed. The Commission has the authority to act at specified times and places, take testimony, and receive evidence as deemed necessary. It can establish bylaws, rules, and regulations to fulfill its functions. Members or agents can take actions authorized by the Commission. The Commission can utilize the U.S. mails like other government agencies. The Secretary must provide requested information to the Commission. The Secretary must provide the Commission with any requested information relevant to its duties regarding the plan referred to in section 101. SEC. 201. STUDY OF NEW PARK SYSTEM AREAS. Section 8 of the Act of August 18, 1970 is amended by inserting "General Authority.--" after "(a)", striking sentences two through seven of subsection (a), and redesignating the last sentence as subsection (e) with the addition of "Authorization of Appropriations.--" before "For the purposes of carrying". Authorization of Appropriations.-- By striking subsection (b) and adding a new subsection (b) for Studies of Areas for Potential Addition, the Secretary must submit a list of recommended areas for study for potential inclusion in the National Park System at the beginning of each calendar year. Energy and Natural Resources of the United States Senate recommends areas for study for potential inclusion in the National Park System based on national significance, suitability, and feasibility criteria. Special consideration is given to themes, sites, and resources not adequately represented in the current National Park System. The National Park System Plan will be developed under the National Park System Reform Act of 1994. No new studies for potential inclusion in the National Park System can be started without specific authorization from Congress. The National Park Service can still conduct preliminary assessments, gather data, provide assistance, and update previous studies. The Secretary must complete studies for potential National Park System inclusion within 3 fiscal years of specific legislation enactment. The Secretary must complete studies for potential National Park System inclusion within 3 fiscal years of specific legislation enactment, with public involvement and consideration of national significance. The Secretary must complete studies for potential National Park System inclusion within 3 fiscal years of specific legislation enactment, with public involvement and consideration of national significance. Each study shall consider whether the area under study possesses nationally significant natural or cultural resources, outstanding recreational opportunities, and is a suitable addition to the system. Factors such as rarity, threats, existing protections, public use potential, and interpretive/educational value must be evaluated. The study for potential National Park System inclusion must evaluate public use potential, interpretive and educational potential, costs, socioeconomic impacts, public support, and appropriate management options. It should also identify alternative protection measures and configurations for long-term resource protection and visitor use. The study for potential National Park System inclusion must evaluate public use potential, interpretive and educational potential, costs, socioeconomic impacts, public support, and appropriate management options. It should also identify alternative protection measures and configurations for long-term resource protection and visitor use. The private sector is appropriate for the area, and each study will recommend the Administration's preferred management option. The Secretary will submit a list of areas to Congress at the beginning of each calendar year along with the annual budget submission. The Secretary must submit a list of areas to Congress annually, prioritizing those with cultural or natural resources for potential addition to the National Park System. Factors such as threats to resource values and cost escalation must be considered in developing the list. The House of Representatives passed the bill on September 28, 1994. Clerk: DONNALD K.
